messages.content:
You are a reference metadata extractor. Analyze citation entries and produce structured JSON output.

Format requirements:
- Return JSON array under "references" key
- Use empty strings for fields not present in the source
- Ensure JSON validity (proper syntax, no trailing commas)
- Include only the JSON structure in your response
- Handle both individual authors and organizational entities

Extract the following metadata from each reference:
• Author information (parse into first_name, middle_name, surname for each author. Or if not parsed, use the original string )
• Title of the work (full_title)
• Publication venue (journal_title)
• Volume and issue numbers
• Page range
• Publication date
• Publisher name and location

References to process:
A J Nicholson. An outline of the dynamics of animal populations. Aust. J. Zool.. 1954. Vol. 2
W S Gurney, S P Blythe, R M Nisbet. Nicholson’s blowflies revisited. Nature. 1980. Vol. 287
T Faria. Periodic solutions for a non-monotone family of delayed differential equations with applications to Nicholson systems. J. Differential Equations. 2017. Vol. 263
Q Zhou. The positive periodic solution for Nicholson-type delay system with linear harvesting terms. Appl. Math. Model.. 2013. Vol. 37
B Liu, S Gong. Permanence for Nicholson-type delay systems with nonlinear density-dependent mortality terms. Nonlinear Anal. RWA. 2011. Vol. 12
T Faria, G Röst. Persistence, permanence and global stability for an n-dimensional Nicholson system. J. Dynam. Differential Equations. 2014. Vol. 26
A S Ackleh, L J Allen, J Carter. Establishing a beachhead: a stochastic population model with an Allee effect applied to species invasion. Theor. Popul. Biol.. 2007. Vol. 71
X Mao. Delay population dynamic and environmental noise. Stoch. Dyn.. 2005. Vol. 5
X Mao. Stochastic Differential Equations and Applications. 2007
A Hening, D H Nguyen. Coexistence and extinction for stochastic Kolmogorov systems. Ann. Appl. Probab.. 2018. Vol. 28
N T Linh, T V Ton. Dynamics of a stochastic ratio-dependent predator-prey model. Anal. Appl.. 2011. Vol. 9
Y Cai, Y Kang, M Banerjee, W Wang. A stochastic SIRS epidemic model with infectious force under intervention strategies. J. Differential Equations. 2015. Vol. 259
Y Cai, J Jiao, Z Gui, Y Liu, W Wang. Environmental variability in a stochastic epidemic model. Appl. Math. Comput.. 2018. Vol. 329
W Guo, Y Cai, Q Zhang, W Wang. Stochastic persistence and stationary distribution in an SIS epidemic model with media coverage. Physica A. 2018. Vol. 492
B Yang, Y Cai, K Wang, W Wang. Global threshold dynamics of a stochastic epidemic model incorporating media coverage. Adv. Differential Equations. 2018. Vol. 2018
B Cao, M Shan, Q Zhang, W Wang. A stochastic SIS epidemic model with vaccination. Physica A. 2017. Vol. 486
H Zhang, Y Cai, S Fu, W Wang. Impact of the fear effect in a prey-predator model incorporating a prey refuge. Appl. Math. Comput.. 2019. Vol. 356
Y Cai, K Wang, W Wang. Global transmission dynamics of a Zika virus model. Appl. Math. Lett.. 2019. Vol. 92
K Song, T Zhang, W Ma. Nontrivial periodic solution of a stochastic non-autonomous model with biodegradation of microcystins. Appl. Math. Lett.. 2019. Vol. 94
W Wang, L Wang, W Chen. Stochastic Nicholson’s blowflies delayed differential equations. Appl. Math. Lett.. 2019. Vol. 87
J K Hill, C D Thomas, O T Lewis. Effects of habitat patch size and isolation on dispersal by hesperia comma butterflies: implications for metapopulation structure. J. Anim. Ecol.. 1996. Vol. 65
A J Terry. Impulsive culling of a structured population on two patches. J. Math. Biol.. 2010. Vol. 61
L Berezansky, L Idels, L Troib. Global dynamics of Nicholson-type delay systems with applications. Nonlinear Anal. RWA. 2011. Vol. 12
D J Higham. An algorithmic introduction to numerical simulation of stochastic differential equations. SIAM Rev.. 2001. Vol. 43

Extract and structure bibliographic data from reference citations.

Processing guidelines:
- Decompose author names: separate first name, middle name/initial, and surname. Or if not parsed, use the original string 
- Include all listed authors in the authors array
- Map each bibliographic element to its corresponding field
- Leave fields as empty strings when data is unavailable
- Return clean JSON only—no formatting markers, explanations, or commentary
- Return empty references array if input contains no citations

Output format:
{
    "references": [
        {
            "reference": {
                "authors": [{"first_name": "", "middle_name": "", "surname": ""} | "original string"],
                "full_title": "",
                "journal_title": "",
                "volume": "",
                "issue": "",
                "pages": "",
                "publication_date": "",
                "publisher": "",
                "publication_place": ""
            }
        }
    ]
}

Extract every full reference from the Input Text and respond ONLY with a JSON object of this shape:

```json
{
  "references": [
    {
      "reference": {
        "authors": [
          {"first_name": "", "middle_name": "", "surname": ""} | "original string"
        ],
        "full_title": "",
        "journal_title": "",
        "volume": "",
        "issue": "",
        "pages": "",
        "publication_date": "",
        "publisher": "",
        "publication_place": ""
      }
    }
  ]
}
```

Requirements:
- All person names must be split into first_name, middle_name (empty if absent), surname. Or if not parsed, use the original string 
- If a field is not present in the text, leave it as "" (or [] for authors).
- If no references exist, output {"references": []}.
- No markdown or extra text—JSON only.

Processing guidelines:
- Decompose author names: separate first name, middle name/initial, and surname. Or if not parsed, use the original string

- Return empty references array if input contains no citations
